content.body: Jake Archibald: good morning! I have a couple of SW patches waiting for review when you get a chance... https://github.com/w3c/ServiceWorker/pull/1620 and https://github.com/w3c/ServiceWorker/pull/1621
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: good morning! I have a couple of SW patches waiting for review when you get a chance... https://github.com/w3c/ServiceWorker/pull/1620 and https://github.com/w3c/ServiceWorker/pull/1621

content.body: Hi annevk: We found some existing issue with `process response donein this comment: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1311/files#r737407947
content.formatted_body: Hi annevk: We found some existing issue with `process response donein this comment: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1311/files#r737407947

content.body: basically we call "done" when the network is done, but we never call it for http-cache/SW. For http-cache it's simple, but not sure yet how to integrate it with SW
annevk:  Maybe `network read complete` flag should be on a response instead of on the fetch, I think that would solve it
content.formatted_body: annevk: Maybe network read complete flag should be on a response instead of on the fetch, I think that would solve it

content.body: How would it get set is the problem, no? It's interesting how the lack of progress events for streams is making a lot of this hard
yea
ideally this should all be related to the streams
Perhaps the solution would be to have some kind of transform stream that reports when EOF is pushed and otherwise forwards
isn't that equivalent to "teeing" the stream and fully reading one side of the tee?
I thought reading had side effects, such as possibly influencing the speed of transfer
yea but not observable side effects
as far as observable behavior is concerned it should be equivalent, of course implementations can do something "faster"
Maybe, I'm not too well-versed in this. It seems rather wasteful, but perhaps with an explanation of what it is doing it could work
but maybe a cleaner solution would be to add some "control-flow" reader to a stream like you suggested
Mattias Buelens do you have thoughts on any of this?
content.formatted_body: Mattias Buelens do you have thoughts on any of this?

content.body: Seems like maybe the cleanest thing would be that FETCH adds a transform stream that implements flush (https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-transformer-flush) but that is otherwise an identity transform stream
annevk: doing ^^^ for only the SW case would solve the problem I think (for HTTP cache we can check cache-state on fetch finale). I'll jot down a revision and see what it looks like
content.formatted_body: annevk: doing ^^^ for only the SW case would solve the problem I think (for HTTP cache we can check cache-state on fetch finale). I'll jot down a revision and see what it looks like

content.body: Teeing and then fully reading one side is not correct, since it doesn't respect backpressure. Piping through an identity transform stream that implements `flush()` would work.
content.formatted_body: Teeing and then fully reading one side is not correct, since it doesn't respect backpressure. Piping through an identity transform stream that implements flush() would work.

content.body: You could also use the promise returned by `pipeTo()` to know when the pipe has completed, and thus when the readable has reached EOF. But a transform stream with `flush()` is probably easier to reason about.
content.formatted_body: You could also use the promise returned by pipeTo() to know when the pipe has completed, and thus when the readable has reached EOF. But a transform stream with flush() is probably easier to reason about.

content.body: great, thanks Mattias Buelens. Getting to it!
content.formatted_body: great, thanks Mattias Buelens. Getting to it!

content.body: Mattias Buelens: how do I define a `[=transform stream=]` with a custom flush, spec-wise? Seems like `{{Transformer}}` is a web-exposed class, while I want to stay in the "internal" realm
content.formatted_body: Mattias Buelens: how do I define a [=transform stream=] with a custom flush, spec-wise? Seems like {{Transformer}} is a web-exposed class, while I want to stay in the "internal" realm

content.body: See https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#other-specs-ts
For an example, see step 5.2 of https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#http-fetch
perfect, thanks!

> <@mattiasbuelens:matrix.org> See https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#other-specs-ts

Seems like `transformAlgorithm` is required though, is there something like an `identityTransformAlgorithm` I can use here or needs to be exposed?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @mattiasbuelens:matrix.org
See https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#other-specs-ts
Seems like transformAlgorithm is required though, is there something like an identityTransformAlgorithm I can use here or needs to be exposed?

content.body: (I only want to customize flush)
Hmm, doesn't seem like it. It's probably easiest to define your own `transformAlgorithm` that simply enqueues the given chunk (using https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#transformstream-enqueue).
content.formatted_body: Hmm, doesn't seem like it. It's probably easiest to define your own transformAlgorithm that simply enqueues the given chunk (using https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#transformstream-enqueue).

content.body: You can copy the phrasing from https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#create-an-identity-transformstream

Done. annevk I think this made https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1311 a lot better... At `fetch finale` the response is either done and can be finalized, or we add a `TransformStream` at that point that reports `done` on `flush`.
content.formatted_body: Done. annevk I think this made https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1311 a lot better... At fetch finale the response is either done and can be finalized, or we add a TransformStream at that point that reports done on flush.

content.body: ... no need to deal with the network thread race conditions

content.body: Noam Rosenthal, annevk, Domenic: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7376
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal, annevk, Domenic: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7376

content.body:
> <@andreubotella:mozilla.org> Noam Rosenthal, annevk, Domenic: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7376

I believe getDeadline should be clamped to always be >=0, if that's missing in the requestIdleCallback spec it's an oversight and I'll add it, thanks for noticing.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @andreubotella:mozilla.org
Noam Rosenthal, annevk, Domenic: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7376
I believe getDeadline should be clamped to always be >=0, if that's missing in the requestIdleCallback spec it's an oversight and I'll add it, thanks for noticing.

content.body: I haven't looked at `requestIdleCallback` in any depth, but this is an issue with the timers
content.formatted_body: I haven't looked at requestIdleCallback in any depth, but this is an issue with the timers

content.body: Andreu Botella (he/they): from the issue it seems like it's only a rIB issue, as that's the only place this deadline is relevant. so I guess I don't fully understand the issue.
content.formatted_body: Andreu Botella (he/they): from the issue it seems like it's only a rIB issue, as that's the only place this deadline is relevant. so I guess I don't fully understand the issue.

content.body: `setTimeout()` timers keeping an entry in the map of active timers even long after their callback has been run
content.formatted_body: setTimeout() timers keeping an entry in the map of active timers even long after their callback has been run

content.body: thus keeping the deadline in the past
even if it's clamped to 0, that's probably not what you want for already-expired timers
right, we now remove them from the list. Why were they kept in the list in the first place and how was that observable?
The timer task (timer initialization steps, step 9) in the spec will not remove the entry from the map of active timers if `repeat` is false
content.formatted_body: The timer task (timer initialization steps, step 9) in the spec will not remove the entry from the map of active timers if repeat is false

content.body: But see the note in step 13
I suspect Chrome does remove it

Andreu Botella (he/they): I see, so for the purpose of repeating intervals, the spec is "lazy" and doesn't actually remove the timers from the map, which would have a strange effect on requestIdleCallback. The safest solution would be that the map value would have a boolean "expired" alongside the timer's deadline to let rIB ignore them
content.formatted_body: Andreu Botella (he/they): I see, so for the purpose of repeating intervals, the spec is "lazy" and doesn't actually remove the timers from the map, which would have a strange effect on requestIdleCallback. The safest solution would be that the map value would have a boolean "expired" alongside the timer's deadline to let rIB ignore them

content.body: Am I getting this correctly now?
Or simply remove the entry from the map after the callback
* Or simply remove the entry from the map after the callback

m.new_content.body: Or simply remove the entry from the map after the callback

content.body: Andreu Botella (he/they): we can't do that because of intervals... repeating means that someone actually canceled that ID
content.formatted_body: Andreu Botella (he/they): we can't do that because of intervals... repeating means that someone actually canceled that ID

content.body: but yea removing them and making sure intervals are handled correctly by rIB would also solve this problem

I noticed this ‚Äìand other timer issues‚Äì while rewriting the implementation of timers in Deno (even though we don't implement `requestIdleCallback` yet), and what I'm doing is just have step 9.5 run the timer initialization steps if `repeat` is true or remove the entry otherwise.
content.formatted_body: I noticed this ‚Äìand other timer issues‚Äì while rewriting the implementation of timers in Deno (even though we don't implement requestIdleCallback yet), and what I'm doing is just have step 9.5 run the timer initialization steps if repeat is true or remove the entry otherwise.

content.body: Would this be an issue for rIC?
this would be good for rIC, all that rIC cares about is the "next active timeout to pop"
